bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, October 12, 1923

div1.p: Carter discusses diseases similar to yellow fever. He suspects Cucuta, Colombia is a yellow fever focal point. He comments on the origins of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Henry Hanson, October 12, 1923
div1.opener:
File
I. H. B.
Hanson
Note this kind of mark (“/”) means
this (“.”) Fault of typewriter
(machine not Laura)
The Johns Hopkins Hospital,
Baltimore, Md/,
Oct/ 12, 1923.
/LC
Dear Hanson:
div1.p: Your letter of Sept. 9th/ reached here yesterday/

What you say about finding relapsing fever at Bucaramanga is
to me extremely interesting/

Gillespie or Gilchrist- I forget which reported as “febris incognita” an epidemic at Dum-
fries, Scotland, in January and February 1826 (?) which he was positive,
“both from clinical symptoms and autopsy, was identical with the yellow
fever that "the eminent Frenchman”, Louis, " had “so well described at Gibraltar”
Its marked characteristics were black vomit and jaundice/ It was, how-
ever, clearly relapsing fever/

Arnott and MacCormack reported the same fever at Glasgow and
Edinburg the same year, in winter & early spring the hemorrhagic symptoms still characterizing it/

Wilkes and Stokes--very great clinicians--reported an epidem-
ic (21 cases and 18 deaths) of “yellow fever of the West Indies” in the
Dublin hospital (December and January of about the same time/ jaundice &
haematamesis

Noc and Nogué reported in 1921 a “fièvre recurrent” about
Dakkar at first considered yellow feverstet and their cases characterized by jaun-
dice and their dying cases by gastric hemorrhage/

Stevanel has reported this last year, on the Gold Coast of
Africa, an “epidemic of spirochaetosis resembling yellow fever/” If I had
only his clinical symptomshistory to go by I would have accepted it as yellow
fever/. As he reports finding a “small number of spirochetes” “rarely over
20 per field.” Both Dr/ Russell, who was down to see me yesterday, and
myself think that he must have been working with the organism of Ober-
meier--certainly no leptospiral infection has ever given smears or sec-
tions like that. He, however, states that it was not the "fièvre recurrent

I suggested, in a portion of my much-neglected History, that the
the
-2-
“Matlazahuatl” on the Mexican Plateau 16th & 17th Century which our American archaeologists are
claiming for yellow fever, was almost certainly a mixture of typhus and re-
lapsing fever/

Keep these things in your mind, and look for spironema even in cases
in which you do see black vomit and jaundice/

I dare not hope that this explanation will hold for all, but I
would give $1,000.00 ($800.00 of which I'd have to borrow!) if it could be
so/

You are very right to take up Stegomyia control of the key-points on
the Magdalena to render them uninfectable as a preliminary, along with, of course, the Caribbean
ports/

I am exceedingly glad to get your letters/ I do not know where
Puerto Santos is/ Is Le Brija the same place we used to call La Brea, where
the oil men are at work?

I still suspect Cucuta/ Have no reason, except it is in the Mara-
caibo basin, which included La Cura where yellow fever was reported in
1916, and Bucaramanga quite certainly got its last big epidemic--my re-
collection is in /12 or /14--from Cucuta (fiebre d'aclimaccion), which
(“protected against the Maracaibo fever”) was endemic there/ I am giving
you a poor reason to suspect it now, as everybody who was is past early child-
hood in 1910 or 1911 must be immune.

About Maracaibo, of course, you have a perfect control in the
American and English (and I fear me German) oil and asphalt men/

Heao--a man whom I totally respect and like--reported several cases
at Puerto Berrio about 1914/ Guiteras and myself stopped at this place to
see him and, form his further description, felt quite certain that the
cases were not yellow fever/ White, I think, accepts them, but we were
closer to the event by some seven years and I cannot/ The specimen Heão
sent to London was also pronounced negative (I think, but am not sure, by
Andrew Balfour/ He Herao is an honest man, however, and a gentleman/
gentleman/

If you see anything of my old friend, Dr. Vengoechia, give
him both my kindest regards and best respects. He is, or was, at Baranquilla

Espundia in Peru (the Ferida brava of the Amazon Valley) is not
an elephantiasis--it is the American Leishmaniasis/ It is absolutely
different in its latter manifestations from the Leishmaniasis of Asia and East
Africa (the “Aleppo button” et al). They have both forms in Brazil--the
latter almost confined to the Coast (introduced I think, by Syrian im-
migrants,)
while there is only espundia is in the back country: up the Amazon and on the
Parana and--I am absolutely certain this is native to America. No morphological
or cultural differences have been found in the parasites. In Brazil,
at any rate, it is quite certainly conveyed by some suctorial fly (nature unknown,)
that lives in some wooded regions and Tartar emetic (intra-venously)
is welnigh as much a specific against it as salvarsan is to syphilis.
I saw 143 cases in the Bahia Hospital.

The British entomologists have reported from the Gold Coast
(Salt Pond especially) the free--or rather profuse-breeding of A. (Ste-
gomyia) aegypti in lagoons and tracks of boys around lagoons them and in mud
puddles generally/ Please have Dunn keep his eyes and mind open to
see if this thing ever occurs in the Americas:-- I mean from egg to
imago. We have hitherto not so found it/ At the same time, both of
us have seen enough of mosquitoes not to refuse to accept what seems
to be a well attested fact because it contravenes the experience we
ourselves have had: For instance, I and none of my gang, have found
Anopheles producing in artificial containers so as to be of sanitary importance in any place
east of the Mississippi. Von Ezdorf: LePrince and Taylor claim that
this is common in Arkansas, even where other breeding places are a-
vailable and where they are not in excessive numbers. I believe it.

Please also, if you can, keep your eyes open of for one, or it
may be two things:

1. For Schistosomiasis mansoni (Bilharsia Mansoni). This was quite
quite
-4-
common in Caracas. Iturbe found one of the snail hosts,
Bullinis contortes, at Caracas

2/ Anything called “el bicho” or “la bicha/” This is the name
that is given by F/ X/ Sigaud (1840-45) to a Brazilian disease, which
I suspect was No/ 1./ The cases are characterized by gangrene of the
rectum. The same disease is described by early Dutch and Portuguese
writers as existing at San Thome and Angola in West Africa in the 16th.
Century. This name, “la bicha,” was the name given by the Brazilian
historians to the first epidemic of yellow fever they had (1586-7) (I am doubtful of this date) in
Pernambuco and Bahia. (“The Epidemic of Celinda”) There is absolutely no question of the nature
of the disease in the Bahia epidemic/ It is beautifully reported by
da Rocha Pitta and probablypossibly came to Pernambuco from Sao Thiago ,Azores, in Fer-
rera de Andrade's expedition.

Père Labat, who, as you know, reported our first generally re-
cognized epidemic of yellow fever in the Americas (1648)--“mal de
Siam” Martinique,----afterwards went to Angola where he claims to have recognized
the same illness and said it should more properly be called “mal
d'Afrique”. He stated that because “a bicha” is among its names in Angola.
If you remember, it was the name given to the epidemic --whatever it
was--at Callao that Leblond and your Peruvian friend (the one who sent
me his monograph criticizing Leblond) differed on. The word was also
used--according to Wm.Willem Pico, for small-pox (?). Of course, it really
means “the creature” and in a very derogatory sense.

About myself, I have had two attacks of angina pectoris. The
first followed what I judge was possibly over-exertion, though I did not
feel it at the time. The second was not. I am here with Tom Brown and
Thayer. No better men could be found. Both attacks were associated with a pylorospasm and I'll give
them a Xmas present if they'll say that the whole thing was only an unu-
sually violent one/ I expect to go to Washington shortly, as soon as I
can, but no sooner than I canshould, and as soon as I can finish the section
that I have almost completed, on the “Place Origin of Yellow Fever”, I
I
-5-
will send you a copy of it for your criticism thereon/. I have made an
absolute volte face from the position I held before I began investigating
and while I would not like to say that anything is proven, I am certain-
ly disinclined to accept it as being of American origin. However, you
will see what evidence I have when I send you the paper. It has involved
a good deal of work, some of it--to me--very difficult. I judge I have
been over over ten thousand pages on this subject from Nauhuatl and Maya
to Flemish and Latin. I can read Portuguese--thank God!--fairly well,
and Dutch (Holland) to some extent.
I think a weeks work as I was working last spring, or--say--six weeks
as I will work now, will enable me to finish this Section and you will
be able to judge then whether my evidence justifies my tentative--it can
be only a tentative--conclusion.

Thayer's examination this moring--he went over me last spring--
was I judge, from the little he said, his expression etc/ favorable. I
will attempt no more field work, however.

I have not written to Mrs/ Hanson, but will do so when I get to
Washington. But for Laura I could not write to you.

One other thing:--and this is the end: If you can find any old
books on Jimenez' Quesada's expedition from Santa Marta to Bogotá or (more
important still) of the two Germans' (Alfinger and ?) from Coro,
one of whom (I think Alfinger) met Quesada at Bogota and the other went
across country to the Magdalena lower down. I will be enormously your debtor if you
will get them for me.
Adios amigo, te doy buenas dichas.

Your letters interest me exceedingly and I will be glad to hear
from you whenever you have time/
